Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at the mountain of laundry on the couch, feeling the weight of my promise to help keep our home running smoothly. My husband had already done the grocery shopping and cooked dinner this week, so it was my turn to tackle the chores. But as I reached for the first shirt, my phone buzzed—a reminder for my volunteer shift at the community center. I was supposed to be there in thirty minutes, and I knew they expected me to be on time, even though a few other volunteers could cover the start if I was late. I could almost hear my husband’s voice in my head, gently reminding me that we agreed to share the load at home. At the same time, I felt the tug of responsibility to the people counting on me at the center. My heart pounded as I stood frozen between the laundry and the door, torn by the demands of being a good wife and a reliable volunteer, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
